   Mg++:1.5 mg/dL, PO4:2.2 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
 .H/O PULMONARY HYPERTENSION (PULM HTN, PHTN)
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
   This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and respiratory
   failure, MAT/a-flutter, who was intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **]
   with MAT/a-fib, respiratory distress, intubated and treated for UTI and
   transferred per family request.
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever
   (101-103), and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate 3.7.  Likely source is
   urinary vs respiratory vs line infection. The patient has been at [**Hospital **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial infections are high on the
   differential. The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial.
   Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter with rapid rate, likely
   infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line infection.  She was placed
   on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna vs effusion vs pulm edema
   vs ARDS.
   - likely secondary to infx per above: continue vanc/[**Last Name (un) 430**]/amikacin.
   - ID c/s today
   - call OSH for sensitivities
   - TTE today to assess for cardiac fxn
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12, trend lactate, trend WBC/diff
   - IV fluid boluses
   - Levophed and Neo to maintain MAP > 65 and UOP > 30cc/hr, but may use
   dopa depending on Echo
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30 if remains in spetic shock
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum
   - check amikacin peak and trough
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - f/u BCx, Ucx, sputum, pull line and culture tip
   - stress dose steriods, increase to solumedrol 60 [**Hospital1 **] (pt was on 2d ago
   at OSH)
   - cooling blankets prn
   .
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. Cardioverted yesterday night into sinus tach
   (130-140s)
   - cont Amio gtt for now, hold nodal agents given hemodynamic instab [**2-25**]
   septic shock per above, wait for TTE
   - repeat ECG in AM
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   - LENI to r/o DVT
   - first set CE neg, will ROMI
   - check dig level
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG here showed
   7.35/74/162/43. AC 540/15/5/100%. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in
   sputum and as well as chronic aspirations. CXR showed b/l diffuse
   infiltrates/effusions R>L. DDx: Multi-focal Pneumonia, pulmonart edema
   Aspiration pneumonitis, effusision, ARDS
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   - Pt likely lives at an elevated PCO2 given elevated Bicarb. Pt also
   autopeeping and thus will increase PEEP to 10 and attempt to decrease
   RR.  Will follow closely with ABG.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt Hct on admission was 21.9. This is down from 25 at the
   OSH. Pt with multiple ecchymosis on exam.  No evidence of active
   bleeding. Other possiblities could be RP or intraperitonea bleed.
   - active T&C 4U
   - Transfuse 2U pRBC and repeat Hct
   - hemolysis labs
   - guaiac stools
   - if continues to drop Hct plan for CT-torso
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Pt plts 125. HIT negative at OSH. Stable, will
   cont to monitor and trend.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - repeat UA/UCx
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum: growing from sputum. Question as to whether
   colonization vs active infection. CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is
   being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - repeat sputum cx
   - cont amikacin
   - started meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   .
   # FEN: NPO, will plan to initiate TF tomorrow. Nutrition consult
   .
   # Access: PICC line (placed at OSH)
   Left fem CVL, left radial a-line
   .
   # PPx: pneumoboots, PPI,
   .
   # Code: FULL CODE
   .
   # Dispo: ICU for now
   .
   # Comm: Family attempted to be contact[**Name (NI) **] at time of admission. Spoke
   with husband at length to update him overnight.
   Husband [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Name (NI) 9775**]) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9776**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2165-8-16**] 06:50 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-8-16**] 09:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2165-8-16**] 10:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory failure, and acute exacerbation.
* She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure.
* She has a fever (103.4Â°F) and is experiencing septic shock, with a lactate level of 3.7 mmol/L.
* She has a history of pulmonary hypertension (PHTN) and is currently receiving treatment for a urinary tract infection (UTI) and pseudomonas in her sputum.
* Her cardiac status is complicated by atrial flutter, which is being managed with amiodarone.
* She has a history of chronic aspirations and is at risk for aspiration pneumonitis.
* Her hemodynamic status is unstable, with a heart rate of 137 bpm, blood pressure of 120/69 mmHg, and a central venous pressure (CVP) of 23 mmHg.
* She has a low hemoglobin level (21.9%) and is receiving transfusions.
* She has a low platelet count (125) and is being monitored for thrombocytopenia.
* She has a history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) and is being treated with steroids.
* She has a PICC line, multi-lumen line, and arterial line in place.
* She is receiving treatment for sepsis, including antibiotics and fluids, and is being monitored closely for signs of organ dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that may arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require further interventions to improve oxygenation and ventilation.
* Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely to be multifactorial, and she may require further treatment to address the underlying causes of her infection.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial flutter and history of pulmonary hypertension may increase her risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of chronic aspirations and use of steroids may increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration pneumonitis or gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Hematological complications: The patient's low hemoglobin and platelet counts may increase her risk of bleeding or hematological complications, such as hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia.
* Infections: The patient's use of antibiotics and steroids may increase her risk of infections, such as Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) or fungal infections.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and use of vasopressors may increase her risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac failure or arrhythmias.

Based on this information, I recommend that the patient continue to receive close monitoring and treatment for her sepsis, respiratory failure, and cardiac complications.

TEXT:

   Assessment and Plan
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
 .H/O PULMONARY HYPERTENSION (PULM HTN, PHTN)
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
   This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and respiratory
   failure, MAT/a-flutter, who was intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **]
   with MAT/a-fib, respiratory distress, intubated and treated for UTI and
   transferred per family request.
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever
   (101-103), and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate 3.7.  Likely source is
   urinary vs respiratory vs line infection. The patient has been at [**Hospital **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial infections are high on the
   differential. The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial.
   Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter with rapid rate, likely
   infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line infection. She has h/o
   proteus UTI and pseudomonas in sputum. She was placed on levophed gtt
   and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   - likely secondary to infx per above: continue vanc/[**Last Name (un) 430**]/amikacin
   - check amikacin trough
   - ID c/s today
   - call OSH for sensitivities
   - TTE today to assess for cardiac fxn
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12, trend lactate, trend WBC/diff
   - IV fluid boluses
   - Levophed and Neo to maintain MAP > 65 and UOP > 30cc/hr, but may use
   dopa depending on Echo
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30 if remains in spetic shock
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - f/u BCx, Ucx, sputum, pull line and culture tip
   - stress dose steriods, increase to solumedrol 60 [**Hospital1 **] (pt was on 2d ago
   at OSH)
   - cooling blankets prn
   .
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation, and d-dimer low so PE unlikely.
   Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely driving her tachycardia.
   Cardioverted yesterday night into sinus tach (130-140s)
   - cont Amio gtt for now, hold nodal agents given hemodynamic instab [**2-25**]
   septic shock per above, wait for TTE
   - repeat ECG in AM
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   - first set CE neg, will ROMI
   - check dig level
   .
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG here showed
   7.35/74/162/43. AC 540/15/5/100%. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in
   sputum and as well as chronic aspirations. CXR showed b/l diffuse
   infiltrates/effusions R>L. DDx: Multi-focal Pneumonia, pulmonart edema
   Aspiration pneumonitis, effusision, ARDS
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   - Pt likely lives at an elevated PCO2 given elevated Bicarb. Pt also
   autopeeping and thus will increase PEEP and attempt to decrease RR.
   Will follow closely with ABG.
   .
   # Oliguria: BUN and Cr are normal right now. However given septic shock
   there is concern for poor renal blood flow, and the possibility for
   development of ATN and future need for CVVH given IVF need.
   - check [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - monitor UOP closely, gentle IVF
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt Hct on admission was 21.9. This is down from 25 at the
   OSH. Pt with multiple ecchymosis on exam.  No evidence of active
   bleeding. Other possiblities could be RP or intraperitoneal bleed.  HCT
   stable now at 31.
   - active T&C 4U
   - follow CBCs
   - hemolysis labs
   - guaiac stools
   - if continues to drop Hct plan for CT-torso
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Pt plts low 100s. HIT negative at OSH. Stable,
   will cont to monitor and trend.
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   .
   # FEN: NPO, will plan to initiate TF tomorrow. Nutrition consult
   .
   # Access: PICC line (placed at OSH)
   Left fem CVL, left radial a-line
   .
   # PPx: pneumoboots, PPI,
   .
   # Code: FULL CODE
   .
   # Dispo: ICU for now
   .
   # Comm: Family attempted to be contact[**Name (NI) **] at time of admission. Spoke
   with husband at length to update him overnight.
   Husband [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Name (NI) 9775**]) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9776**]

   Nutrition:

   Arterial Line - [**2165-8-16**] 10:30 PM

   Stress ulcer: PPI

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary hypertension, and chronic respiratory failure. She was admitted to the hospital with acute respiratory distress and was intubated. She has been diagnosed with septic shock, acute respiratory failure, and possible pulmonary embolism. She is currently receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to be multifactorial, with possible sources including urinary tract infection, respiratory tract infection, or line infection. The patient's hypotension is likely to be related to her tachycardia, which is contributing to her low blood pressure.
2. Acute respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure is likely to be related to her COPD and possible pulmonary embolism. She is receiving mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
3. Pulmonary embolism: The patient has a history of pulmonary hypertension and chronic respiratory failure, which may increase her risk of developing a pulmonary embolism. A computed tomography (CT) scan or ventilation-perfusion scan may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's septic shock and possible pulmonary embolism may increase her risk of developing renal failure. Monitoring of her urine output and electrolyte levels is essential to prevent and treat renal failure.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to be related to her bleeding and possible gastrointestinal bleeding. Transfusion of packed red blood cells may be necessary to treat her anemia.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to be related to her septic shock and possible disseminated intravascular coagulation. Monitoring of her platelet count and transfusion of platelets may be necessary to treat her thrombocytopenia.
7. Infection: The patient's septic shock is likely to be related to an infection, which may be related to her urinary tract, respiratory tract, or line infection. Antibiotics and antifungal therapy may be necessary to treat her infection.
8. Organ dysfunction: The patient's septic shock and possible pulmonary embolism may increase her risk of developing organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, and cardiovascular dysfunction.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is assessed as severe sepsis with organ dysfunction. The plan is to continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy, and to manage her septic shock with vasopressors and antibiotics. The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia will be monitored and treated as necessary. The patient's renal function will be closely monitored, and dialysis may be necessary if her kidney function deteriorates. The patient's infection will be treated with antibiotics and antifungal therapy, and her organ dysfunction will be managed with supportive care.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt
   active bleeding.
   - active T&C
   - transfuse 1 unit of blood
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.

   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.

   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at

   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying

She was admitted to the hospital with respiratory distress and was intubated. The patient has developed septic shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and acute kidney injury (AKI). She has also developed a severe metabolic acidosis, with a lactate level of 5.7 mmol/L.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 11 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.7 g/dL

* Electrolytes: sodium 134 mmol/L, potassium 4.3 mmol/L, chloride 97 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan: not performed

The patient's medical history includes:

* Pulmonary hypertension
* Chronic steroid use
* History of respiratory failure

The patient's current medications include:

* Linezolid

* Flagyl
* Voriconazole
* Pantoprazole
* Dopamine
* Levophed
* Neo

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Aggressive supportive care for septic shock
* Broad empiric antibacterial and fungal coverage
* Continuous cardiac output monitoring

* Continue vent support
* ARDS net TVs
* Weaning oxygen therapy

The patient's prognosis is grim, and the medical team is discussing goals of care with the family. The patient remains a full code.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

* Worsening septic shock and MODS
* Development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Progression of acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Development of liver failure
* Development of gastrointestinal bleeding
* Development of cardiac arrhythmias
* Development of coagulopathy
* Development of sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy

The patient's family is being updated regularly on her condition, and the medical team is working to address their goals of care.

   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30

   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.

   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications

   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on

   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would

s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of COPD, respiratory failure, and chronic steroid use. She was admitted to the ICU with septic shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and acute kidney injury (AKI). She has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, and mechanical ventilation. Her condition has continued to deteriorate, with worsening lactic acidosis, hypercapnia, and hypoxia.

The patient has a complex medical condition with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), including septic shock, ARDS, and AKI. She has a high risk of mortality and is unlikely to recover without aggressive supportive care.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to continue, with a high risk of mortality.
2. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is likely to worsen, with a high risk of mortality.
3. AKI: The patient's AKI is likely to progress, with a high risk of mortality.
4. Lactic acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis is likely to worsen, with a high risk of mortality.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely to worsen, with a high risk of bleeding.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to worsen, with a high risk of bleeding.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen, with a high risk of hypoxia.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen, with a high risk of mortality.
9. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest risk is high, with a high risk of mortality.

The patient requires aggressive supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient's family has been informed of her condition and the high risk of mortality. The patient remains full code.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt
   active bleeding.
   - active T&C
   - transfuse 1 unit of blood
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now. D/C tubefeeds.
   Glycemic Control:  HISS.
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2165-8-16**] 10:30 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-8-17**] 03:27 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: boots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:  elevate HOB
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Will speak to family today about pt
   condition
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU level of care

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory failure, and chronic steroid use. She was admitted to the hospital with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), septic shock, and acute kidney injury (AKI). She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. Her condition has deteriorated, with worsening pulmonary congestion, bilateral pleural effusions, and acute respiratory failure.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has developed septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition. She is at risk of further deterioration and organ failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, with worsening hypercarbia and hypoxia. She is at risk of further deterioration and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's AKI is severe, and she is at risk of further deterioration and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular status is unstable, with tachycardia, hypotension, and potential cardiac asystole.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has developed a coagulopathy, with increased PT/PTT, LDH, and thrombocytopenia. She is at risk of bleeding complications.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is worsening, and she is at risk of further deterioration and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Abdominal complications: The patient has abdominal striae with oozing fluid, and she is at risk of further complications, including bleeding and perforation.
8. Infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is at risk of further infection complications.
9. Pseudomonas infection: The patient has a pseudomonas infection in her sputum, and she is at risk of further complications, including sepsis and respiratory failure.
10. Diabetes insipidus: The patient is at risk of developing diabetes insipidus due to her chronic steroid use and potential pituitary dysfunction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely.
2. Administer antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed to treat the patient's infections.
3. Maintain mechanical ventilation and adjust settings as necessary to optimize the patient's respiratory status.
4. Continue to provide hemodynamic support with vasopressors and fluids as necessary.
5. Consult with a nephrologist to discuss the patient's AKI and potential dialysis.
6. Consult with a cardiologist to discuss the patient's cardiovascular instability and potential cardiac asystole.
7. Monitor the patient's coagulopathy and bleeding risk closely.
8. Consult with a gastroenterologist to discuss the patient's abdominal complications and potential bleeding and perforation.
9. Consider consulting with an infectious disease specialist to discuss the patient's infections and potential complications.
10. Monitor the patient's diabetes insipidus and adjust treatment as necessary.

   gram negative rods
   Blood, mycolytic blood cultures pending
   Urine culture pending.
   CXR: Worsening pulmonary congestion bilaterally. Pleural effusions
   bilaterally. RIJ in place.
   Assessment and Plan
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
 .H/O PULMONARY HYPERTENSION (PULM HTN, PHTN)
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt
   active bleeding.
   - active T&C
   - transfuse 1 unit of blood
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now. D/C tubefeeds.
   Glycemic Control:  HISS.
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2165-8-16**] 10:30 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-8-17**] 03:27 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: boots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:  elevate HOB
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Will speak to family today about pt
   condition
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU level of care

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary hypertension, and chronic steroid use. She was admitted to the hospital with acute respiratory failure, intubated, and treated for urinary tract infection (UTI). She was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to worsening respiratory failure and sepsis.

The patient's current condition is critical, with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), septic shock, and acute kidney injury (AKI). She has a high risk of developing further complications, including multi-organ failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and bleeding.

Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to her underlying conditions, including COPD, pulmonary hypertension, and chronic steroid use.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient has developed ARDS, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by inflammation and damage to the lungs.
3. Septic Shock: The patient has developed septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by hypotension, tachycardia, and decreased peripheral resistance.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has developed AKI, which is a common complication of sepsis and other critical illnesses.
5. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): The patient has a high risk of developing DIC, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by widespread clotting of blood vessels.
6. Bleeding: The patient has a high risk of bleeding due to her underlying conditions, including chronic steroid use and anticoagulation therapy.
7. Pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing pneumonia due to her underlying conditions, including COPD and pulmonary hypertension.

Treatment Plan:

1. Continue to provide supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and fluids.
2. Continue to treat the patient's underlying infections, including UTI and pneumonia.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's coagulation status and consider anticoagulation therapy if necessary.
5. Consider activated protein C therapy to prevent further bleeding.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider intubation if necessary.
7. Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Consider consulting with a specialist, such as a pulmonologist or nephrologist, to help manage the patient's underlying conditions.
3. Consider performing further diagnostic tests, such as echocardiography or CT scans, to help guide treatment.
4. Consider transferring the patient to a higher level of care, such as a cardiothoracic intensive care unit, if necessary.
5. Continue to provide emotional support and education to the patient and her family.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt
   active bleeding.
   - active T&C
   - transfuse 1 unit of blood
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   ICU Care

   55 yo F with septic shock and MODS (ARF, ARDS, worsening lactic

   pressors with progressive acidosis and rising lactate despite

s   RR 26   96%  cvp 11    11L +

   Micro reviewed
   Primary issues include:
     * Septic shock

     * resp failure/ards/pulm edema,
     * persistent tachycardia

     * persistent bandemia,
     * anemia

     * altered level of consciousness
   MODS in setting of progressive septic shock.  Continues to decline
   despite aggressive management. Her prognosis for recovery is grim.  We
   continue to  update family and address goals of care.  Will continue
   aggressive supportive care for septic shock, maintaining maps > 60 with
   pressors. Is now 11L pos.  Her oxygenation remains poor on 100%
   fio2/peep 18.  Rising lactate raises concern for ischemic bowel in
   setting of persistent shock and pressors. Continue broad empiric
   antibacterial and fungal coverage-linezolid, amikacin (follow levels),
   [**Last Name (un) 430**], flagyl, and vori. D/c bactrim as low suspicion for PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) **] data.
   Continue stress hydrocort.  Continuous cardiac output monitoring w/
   vigileo. Trend lactate, lytes, SVO2.  Continue vent support, ards net
   TVs.  We are unable to wean O2.  She is maxed on what we can do from
   vent standpoint in term of her acid base status.  Renal is following,
   but given grim prognosis, CVVH would only be temporizing. We again
   discussed xigris, but her progressive coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory failure, who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), septic shock, and acute kidney injury (AKI). She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition has been deteriorating, with worsening lactic acidosis, persistent tachycardia, and declining oxygenation. She has been diagnosed with septic shock, MODS, and ARF, and is at high risk of mortality.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to worsen, and she may require further pressor support and aggressive fluid resuscitation.
2. MODS: The patient's MODS is likely to progress, and she may require further support with mechanical ventilation and pressors.
3. ARF: The patient's ARF is likely to worsen, and she may require dialysis.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen, and she may require further support with mechanical ventilation.
5. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen, and she may require further antibiotics and supportive care.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely to worsen, and she may require further anticoagulation therapy.
7. Bleeding: The patient is at risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia.
8. Ischemic Bowel: The patient's rising lactate levels raise concern for ischemic bowel, particularly in the setting of persistent shock and pressors.
9. Cardiac Arrest: The patient is at risk of cardiac arrest, particularly in the setting of septic shock and MODS.
10. Mortality: The patient's prognosis is grim, and she is at high risk of mortality.

Recommendations:

1. Continue aggressive supportive care for septic shock, including pressor support and fluid resuscitation.
2. Continue broad empiric antibiotic and fungal coverage.
3. Consider dialysis for ARF.
4. Continue mechanical ventilation support for respiratory failure.
5. Monitor the patient's coagulopathy and bleeding risk closely.
6. Consider activated protein C therapy to improve coagulopathy.
7. Monitor the patient's lactate levels closely to assess for ischemic bowel.
8. Continue cardiac output monitoring with Vigileo.
9. Trend the patient's laboratory values, including lactate, lytes, and SVO2.
10. Discuss the patient's prognosis and goals of care with the family.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30 if remains in septic shock
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, bactrim for PCP (use
   of chronic steroids)
   - check amikacin peak and trough
   - empiric coverage with meropenem
   - CXR in AM
   - f/u blood, urine and sputum cultures
   - Trend WBC count fever curve.
   - call OSH for sensi
   - stress dose steriods
   - cooling blankets prn
   - ID consult in AM regarding abx regimen
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema, unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying pseudomonas
   pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on BiPAP, but
   required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening hypercarbia and
   hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum and as well as
   chronic aspirations. CXR showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia.
   - If continue Amio, need to switch to PO.
   - ECHO ordered
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   - LENI to r/o DVT
   #. DIC:. HIT negative at OSH. Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt Hct on admission was 21.9. This is down from 25 at the
   OSH. Pt with multiple ecchymosis on exam.  No evidence of active
   bleeding. Other possiblities could be RP or intraperitonea bleed.
   - active T&C 4U
   - Transfuse 2U pRBC and repeat Hct
   - hemolysis labs
   - guaiac stools
   - if continues to drop Hct plan for CT-torso
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - repeat UA/UCx
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum: growing from sputum. Question as to whether
   colonization vs active infection. CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is
   being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary hypertension, and chronic steroid use. She was admitted to the hospital with respiratory distress, intubated, and treated for urinary tract infection (UTI). She was transferred to the ICU due to septic shock, respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury.

The patient's condition is complicated by multiple factors, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever, and increased respiratory rate, and has a high likelihood of nosocomial infections.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has COPD and has developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with bilateral diffuse infiltrates and effusions.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is at risk for dialysis.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's fast heart rate is likely contributing to her hypotension and may be driven by sepsis, pain, and underlying pulmonary hypertension.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and she has multiple ecchymoses on examination, which may be related to recent bleeding or intraperitoneal bleeding.
6. DIC: The patient has a high likelihood of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) due to sepsis and bleeding.
7. UTI: The patient has a growing proteus infection in her urine and is being treated with amikacin.
8. Pseudomonas pneumonia: The patient has a growing pseudomonas infection in her sputum and is being treated with meropenem.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient is at risk for further organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and kidney injury.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient may require mechanical ventilation and may be at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient may require dialysis and may be at risk for chronic kidney disease.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's fast heart rate may lead to cardiac arrest and may be difficult to manage with medications.
5. Anemia: The patient's low hemoglobin level may lead to further bleeding and may require transfusions.
6. DIC: The patient is at risk for further bleeding and may require platelet transfusions.
7. UTI: The patient may develop further complications related to her UTI, including kidney damage and sepsis.
8. Pseudomonas pneumonia: The patient may develop further complications related to her pseudomonas infection, including respiratory failure and sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's septic shock with IV fluids, vasopressors, and antibiotics.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation as necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's acute kidney injury with fluid management and dialysis as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's tachycardia and adjust medications as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's DIC and transfuse platelets as necessary.
7. Continue to manage the patient's UTI with antibiotics and monitor for further complications.
8. Continue to manage the patient's pseudomonas pneumonia with antibiotics and monitor for further complications.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema, unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying pseudomonas
   pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on BiPAP, but
   required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening hypercarbia and
   hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum and as well as
   chronic aspirations. CXR showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia.
   - If continue Amio, need to switch to PO.
   - ECHO ordered
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   - LENI to r/o DVT
   #. DIC:. HIT negative at OSH. Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt Hct on admission was 21.9. This is down from 25 at the
   OSH. Pt with multiple ecchymosis on exam.  No evidence of active
   bleeding. Other possiblities could be RP or intraperitonea bleed.
   - active T&C 4U
   - Transfuse 2U pRBC and repeat Hct
   - hemolysis labs
   - guaiac stools
   - if continues to drop Hct plan for CT-torso
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - repeat UA/UCx
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum: growing from sputum. Question as to whether
   colonization vs active infection. CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is
   being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory failure, and chronic steroid use. She was initially admitted to the hospital with respiratory distress, intubated, and treated for urinary tract infection (UTI) and transferred to the ICU due to worsening condition. The patient has developed septic shock, acute renal failure, and respiratory failure, with a high suspicion of nosocomial infections. She is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including linezolid, amikacin, and meropenem, and has been started on voriconazole for possible fungal infection.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis and septic shock: The patient's condition is already critical, and further deterioration is possible.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has developed acute renal failure, and further kidney damage is a concern.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration is possible.
4. Pneumonia: The patient has pseudomonas pneumonia, and further development of pneumonia is possible.
5. Line infection: The patient has a multi-lumen line, and the risk of line infection is high.
6. VRE and MRSA infections: The patient has a history of VRE and MRSA infections, and further development of these infections is possible.
7. Fungal infection: The patient is at risk of developing a fungal infection due to chronic steroid use.
8. DIC: The patient has developed DIC, and further deterioration is possible.
9. Anemia: The patient has developed anemia, and further blood loss is a concern.
10. UTI: The patient has a UTI, and further development of UTI is possible.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent further complications and improve outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory failure, and chronic steroid use. She was initially admitted to the hospital with septic shock and was transferred to the ICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is severe sepsis with multi-organ failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury (AKI), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). She is also experiencing tachycardia, fever, and hypotension.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated lactate levels, indicating tissue hypoperfusion, and abnormal electrolyte levels, including hypokalemia and hypophosphatemia. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) results show respiratory acidosis, metabolic acidosis, and non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.

The patient's medical treatment includes:

1. Antibiotics: Amikacin, meropenem, and linezolid for coverage of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Gram-negative rods, and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE).
2. Vasopressors: Norepinephrine and dopamine to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg.
3. Dialysis: Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) to manage AKI.
4. Anticoagulation: Warfarin for DIC, but hold due to bleeding and thrombocytopenia.
5. Sedation: None at the moment.

The patient's physical examination shows:

1. Intubated with a large obese female with multiple ecchymoses, cool extremities, and acutely distressed.
2. Tachycardic with a heart rate of 127 beats per minute (bpm).
3. Hypotensive with a blood pressure of 103/53 mmHg.
4. Respiratory failure with a P/F ratio of 68.
5. Abdominal tenderness with a large hematoma on the right lateral abdomen and a draining skin lesion on the right lower quadrant (RLQ).

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, including ARDS, AKI, and DIC.
2. Pseudomonas aeruginosa pneumonia and urinary tract infection.
3. Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE) infection.
4. Hypotension and shock.
5. Acute respiratory failure.
6. Acute kidney injury.
7. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
8. Abdominal compartment syndrome.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued antibiotic therapy for coverage of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Gram-negative rods, and VRE.
2. Maintenance of mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg with vasopressors.
3. Dialysis to manage AKI.
4. Anticoagulation therapy to manage DIC.
5. Sedation to manage tachycardia and agitation.
6. Close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings.
7. Consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) for severe respiratory failure.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill female with severe sepsis, multi-organ failure, and potential complications, including ARDS, AKI, and DIC. Her treatment plan includes aggressive antibiotic therapy, vasopressors, dialysis, and anticoagulation therapy, as well as close monitoring of her vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65.
   Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - discussed w/ family pt started on CVVH
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - patient is being dialyzed
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter. Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Sepsis and persistent fevers are likely the
   cause of her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Currently aniuric.
   - being dialyzed.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s Hct currently stable at 26.1.
   - active T&C
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid, total output ~3L. KUB done on [**8-17**]
   did not show anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR

   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.

   Glycemic Control:  HISS.
